1064.description: A makes the mistake of thinking aerself a criminal; then ae discovers that ae is not a criminal * A has assumed the furtive manner of a criminal for so long that it has become habitual with aer and ae cannot act like an honest man **

1065.description: A, giving ten years of aer life to a miserly uncle, U, in exchange for a college education, loses aer ambition and enterprise * A’s uncle, U, has promised A all that ae has when ae dies, but U dies a bankrupt; and A is thrown upon the world with abilities obscured and enterprise strangled **

1066.description: A, an escaped prisoner, finds it impossible to free aerself of aer handcuffs; and when, in desperation, ae appeals for help to a stranger, A-4, A-4 notifies a police officer, A-6, and A is recaptured

1067.description: B fails to understand how aer fretful disposition makes aerself and all around aer unhappy * B, overhearing a conversation which brings home to aer a bitter truth regarding aer unpleasant disposition, alters aer mental attitude and undergoes a beneficial character change **

1068.description: B comes to understand the evil of aer selfish outlook upon life when one of aer children, CH, dies

description: B, over the dead body of aer daughter, D-B

1070.description: A, on trial for murder, could establish an alibi and prove aer innocence—but only by a dishonorable act * A could save aer life by revealing a secret that would compromise the good name of B **

1071.description: A finds that the duties of aer position are so numerous it is physically impossible for aer to carry them out

1072.description: A’s high official position makes it impossible for aer, in aer own person, to acquire information which ae thinks of first importance

1073.description: A, a successful business man, has an overwhelming desire to break away from commercial affairs and go adventuring in quest of Romance * Only the fear of public opinion restrains aer

1074.description: A, a writer, discovers that ae is losing aer grip on aer reading public and is becoming unable to write salable material

1076.description: A, supposed to be a hoodlum, is transformed into a gentleman in an astonishingly-short period of time * A, transformed almost over night from a hoodlum into a cultured gentleman, imparts to B, aer friend, the secret of aer surprising rehabilitation **

1077.description: A calls at a pawnshop to redeem an object, X, pawned by aer friend, A-2, who has died leaving the pledge unredeemed * A has lost the ticket of a pawned object, X. and the pawnbroker will not give up the pledge without cne ticket **

1078.description: A is obsessed with fear of a pursuing peril * A, obsessed with fear of a pursuing peril, seeks to gain contentment of mind **

1079.description: A’s character weakness is betting; and ae seems unable to conquer the failing although ae invariably suffers loss

1080.description: A, a reporter, assigned to “cover” a certain story and finding it impossible, decides to write up an imaginary interview, pretending it is bona fide

1081.description: A finds it beyond aer power, in any ordinary manner, to secure a man of proven courage for a dangerous piece of work * A proceeds by secret enterprise to find a man of courage **

1083.description: A lacks initiative, and the ability unaided to advance aer material fortunes * A secures the help of B, a woman friend, to aid aer in a difficult enterprise **

1084.description: A seeks to forward an honest enterprise but lacks the means to finance it * A, in order to secure means to forward an honest enterprise, becomes a bootlegger for a time **

1085.description: A would like to save aer friend, A-2, from disaster, but money is necessary—and A has no money

1086.description: A would like to achieve a lofty enterprise, but is so poor ae cannot finance the undertaking

1087.description: A, a crook, would like to restore some of aer ill-gotten gains, but finds it difficult without revealing aer culpability

1088.description: A’s happiness is wrapped up in aer ambition * A lacks ingenuity and the power to force circumstances to contribute their utmost in forwarding aer undertakings **

1089.description: A seeks to find the relatives of CH, a foundling, of whom ae has taken charge * A writes to government authorities sending a copy of a coat of arms found on a foundling. CH’s, coat, but receives no information regarding CH **

1090.description: A is hampered in aer work, and aer success imperiled, by a lack of new ideas

1091.description: A’s knowledge of the profession ae seeks to follow has been obtained solely by reading stories about it; ae has had no practical experience

1092.description: A reaches a point in aer chosen work where aer ingenuity and enterprise grow stale and will not help aer onward

1094.description: A is a celebrity; and the written requests for aer autograph become so numerous that they interfere seriously with aer work

1095.description: A seeks to free aerself from certain meddlesome influences that interfere seriously with the practice of aer profession

1096.description: A, a playwright, having no new ideas for a play, goes forth in quest of them

1098.description: A is a subordinate, and considered mentally inferior * A, a subordinate, attacks a problem that defies solution by aer superiors, and solves it, thereby winning just recognition and preferment **

1100.description: B’s happiness and success hang upon aer successful impersonation of a boy * B, impersonating a boy, is subjected to the rough pranks of aer male companions, who do not suspect aer true sex **

1101.description: A seeks to overcome personal limitations in an honest enterprise by a resort to dishonest methods

1102.description: A, wealthy and too old to have aer “fling,” gives A-2, a spendthrift, a large sum of money to squander as ae sees fit * A hopes to enjoy A-2’s spendthrift experiences second-hand **

1103.description: A, an elderly writer who runs out of ideas, copies material which aer friend, A-2, another writer long dead, wrote in aer younger days

1104.description: A’s ignoble weakness is lack of courage in investigating events that have great news value; for A is a newspaper reporter, and news is aer stock in trade * A, a coward, by deliberately forcing aerself into risky situations in order to acquire first-hand information, develops courage, transforms aer character, and becomes a “star” reporter **

1105.description: B is young and pretty, and believes that Youth, seeking self-expression, is warranted in overriding any and all conventions

1106.description: B, of an humble station in life, yearns for social prestige * B pretends that ae is entertaining a duke, AX **

1108.description: A is so preoccupied with business affairs that, while ae intends writing to aer son, SN, ae somehow never gets around to it

1109.description: A, a simple mountaineer, comes to a large city in pursuit of an enemy, A-3 * A, from the mountains, seeking aer enemy, A-3, in the city, is so overawed and impressed by aer unfamiliar environment that aer enmity fades away **

1110.description: A has committed a crime but has never fallen under suspicion * A’s guilty conscience handicaps aer in the field of enterprise **

1112.description: A finds that aer obligations as a “quack” doctor are too difficult for aer powers

1113.description: A has a theory that the perfume of flowers may be blended into musical conceptions

1114.description: A, private secretary to A-9, knows that A-9 is jealously guarding some weighty secret * A’s curiosity gets the better of aer and ae meddles with the personal affairs of A-9 **

1115.description: A seeks to be loyal to aer friend, A-2, but certain conditions render it difficult

1116.description: A is hastening across the ocean on a fast steamer in order to carry out an important enterprise * A, engaged in an important enterprise, is delayed in mid-ocean by an accident to aer steamer; the vessel’s wireless is out of commission and A faces failure in a pet undertaking **

1117.description: A, a somnambulist, deceives aerself in a certain enterprise by opposing, in an unconscious state, all the efforts of aer waking moments

1118.description: B, a banker’s spouse, trying to subscribe to the social conventions of a farming community, finds aer efforts embarrassing and distasteful

1119.description: B, who lacks every qualification of a successful writer, nevertheless believes aerself highly gifted as a novelist

1120.description: B, unhappy because of A’s sins, appeals to God to save aer

1121.description: B is ambitious to “get ahead,” to advance aerself in aer chosen line of work; but ae has difficulties that are disheartening

1122.description: A manufactures a hand-made product in a worthy manner no machinery can duplicate * A, by manufacturing a hand-made product by machinery, on a large scale, and so keeping up with the demand, will amass wealth; but the standard of quality will be lowered **

1123.description: A, brother of SR-A and aer only living relative, is poor, while SR-A is wealthy and unmarried * A, poor, will not inherit the money of aer wealthy sister, SR-A, if ae marries, as ae seems likely to do **

1124.description: A, in aer absent-minded moments, mechanically draws odd designs on a piece of paper, unaware of what ae is doing, or that it may have an adverse effect upon some of aer secret enterprises

1126.description: A is a bibulous person, and aer ultimatum from aer doctor is this: “Either quit drinking, or resign yourself to die within a few months”

1127.description: A is a cousin of CN, and CN is to inherit the wealth of a deceased relative, A-8. If CN were out of the way, A would be the legal heir

1130.description: A a doctor, who is about to leave aer office on a night emergency call, is made a prisoner by mysterious strangers, AX, AX, AX, and spirited away

1131.description: A’s obstacle to enterprise is laziness; and ae submits to it cheerfully

1132.description: A’s character weakness is superstition * A is so superstitious that it prevents aer from winning success in aer enterprises **

1133.description: A is an agnostic who, in aer arrogance and presumption, defies a Higher Power

1134.description: A, a very ordinary young man, suddenly becomes afflicted with megalomania, and aer character is completely changed * A, who was timid and shirked enterprise, undergoes a character change which impels aer to rush audaciously into the most difficult undertakings **

description: B sends a telegram to aer maid, B-7, to “Come at once” * B

1138.description: A seeks professionally to secure a desired object. X, from B * A, seeking to secure a desired object, X, from B, finds the object so dearly prized because of family associations that B will not part with it at any price **

1139.description: A is a profligate son who seeks to borrow money of A-8 on the prospect of inheriting the estate of aer wealthy father, F-A, A-8 is skeptical regarding A’s inheriting the estate

1140.description: A, publicly, is honest and prosperous, but privately ae is a transgressor * A desires a piece of ground on which to build a mansion. The ground is owned by A-8, a poor man, in whose family it has been for generations. Influenced by family sentiment, A-8 refuses to sell **

1141.description: A has a violent distaste for ghost stories and stories of the supernatural * A pretends to be ill in order to avoid listening to ghost stories **

1144.description: A, a crook, seeks by substituting a worthless counterfeit for the valuable original, to secure an object carefully safeguarded

1145.description: A, a crook, seeks unlawful gain by selling A-8 an object, X, which A-8 already owns

1146.description: A, a crook, in order to carry out a crafty enterprise, disguises aerself as a person of wealth and social standing

1147.description: A, poor, at the request of a rich man, A-8, leaves with A-8 a valuable object, X, which ae has in aer possession and wishes to sell * A calls on A-8 for a valuable object, X, which A had left with A-8, in the hope of making a sale; but A-8 declares A never left X with aer, and has A ejected from the premises **

1149.description: A is a lad away from home, very unhappy because ae does not receive letters from home as all aer other young friends do * A, lonely, and never receiving any letters from aer home folk, writes letters to aerself and shows them to aer friends **

1150.description: A is a coward who seeks, by arrogant boasting, to convince everybody that ae is a hero

1151.description: B simulates ignorance regarding a certain compromising event in aer life * B, in order to avoid slander and evil gossip and protect a daughter, D-A, who is about to marry a man of wealth and social position, seeks to hush up a possible scandal in aer own life **

1152.description: B is the owner of a gem so valuable that ae fears to wear it in public; so ae keeps it in a strong box and wears a replica of it which is of comparatively little value. The fact that ae owns the real stone is well known, and the counterfeit is supposed to be the original

1153.description: B fails in an undertaking dear to aer heart * B, failing in an undertaking dear to aer heart, seeks to make others think ae has succeeded **

1155.description: B, the friend of A, learns that A is desperately involved in debt * B, unknown to A, settles with A’s creditors and frees A from debt **

1156.description: B innocently commits a transgression * B, innocently committing a transgression, for fear of the law keeps the transgression a close secret **

1157.description: B is forced to weep at an appointed time; and A strikes aer in order to make aer grief more realistic

1158.description: B, traveling alone, invents a fictitious aunt, AUX, as a chaperone

1159.description: B pretends ae has been injured by an automobile in order to collect damages from the owner of the car, A-4

description: A’s friend, A-2, is the sole support of aer parents, F-A and M-A * A’s friend, A-2, the sole support of aer parents, dies

1161.description: A, falling in with A-4, a stranger who has been injured in an accident, agrees to take over an enterprise which the accident prevents A-4 from finishing * A, in in order to help A-4, poses as A-4 **

1162.description: A induces a friend, A-2, to play the role of A-5 in order to carry out an enterprise in which the presence of A-5 is necessary

1164.description: A, having invited friends to meet a celebrity, A-4, who does not arrive, persuades A-8 to impersonate A-4 in order that the guests may not be disappointed

1165.description: A is an art collector * X1 and X2 are very rare and valuable art objects, the only two in the world ** A owns an objet d’art, X1; and ae buys X2, as ae supposes, which is an exact duplicate of X1, from A-5, only to discover that ae has repurchased X1 which the scheming A-5 had stolen from aer collection ***

1167.description: A, for worthy purposes, plays the role of a fictitious criminal, A-5 * A, for worthy purposes playing the role of a fictitious criminal, A-5, is sought by the police for a crime committed by the real A-5 **

1168.description: A, inspired by altruistic motives, assumes the name and character of A-2, using A-2’s clothes and other belongings, and seeking to carry out an enterprise begun by A-2 * A, posing as A-2, does not know that A-2 is a transgressor **

1169.description: A seeks to demonstrate aer ability to enact a certain role in a forthcoming play * A, in order to prove aer ability to enact a certain role in a forthcoming play, assumes the role off the stage **

1170.description: A, wealthy and of high social standing, desires adventures in the underworld * A, desiring adventures in the underworld and unable to realize aer desire in aer own character, assumes a fictitious character **

1171.description: B’s father, F-B, is suspected of a certain crime * B, in order to save aer father, F-B, who is suspected of a certain crime, confesses that ae is the culprit ** A, B’s best friend, in order to save B, who is suspected of a certain crime, declares that ae alone is guilty ***

1172.description: B’s striking physical resemblance to B-5, a criminal, causes aer to be suspected of a crime

1173.description: A, a pretender, encounters B, who is also a pretender * A and B are pretenders, yet neither knows that the other is not what ae or ae seems to be **

1174.description: A and A-2 are crooks, seeking escape through the closing net of the law * A and A-2, crooks trying for a “get-away” after a successful “job,” slip through the police net, A-6, A-6, A-6, when A disguises aerself as a woman **

1176.description: A, a crook, is trapped and surrounded by officers of the law, A-6, A-6, A-6 * A, a crook trapped and surrounded by officers of the law, A-6, A-6, A-6, escapes by pretending to be another A-6 who is hunting for aerself **

1177.description: A, a banker, has juggled with the bank’s funds * A, a transgressor, covers up aer criminal acts by a painstaking simulation of honor and excellence **

1178.description: A, highly respected in aer community, has committed a murder * A buries the body of aer murdered victim, A-8, in a swamp and, by aer usual exemplary conduct, seeks to escape suspicion **

1179.description: A is a crirninal who is posing as an officer of the law hunting for another crirninal * A, a criminal, poses as an officer of the law looking for A-5, another criminal. Authorities pick up A-5, turn aer over to A, and A starts with aer prisoner for the scene of A-5’s crime—and aer own **

1180.description: A, a crook, in order to overcome the difficulties of a certain enterprise, impersonates a celebrated novelist, A-4 * A, a crook impersonating a celebrated novelist, A-4, proceeds to a small town and becomes the lion of a ladies’ literary society **

1181.description: A is a transgressor who poses as an honest man for the purpose of carrying out another transgression

1182.description: A, through no fault of aer own, is estranged from aer parents, F-A and M-A * A, estranged from aer parents, F-A and M-A, effects a reconciliation with them by proving aer worth in an assumed character as an Unknown **

1183.description: A, in order to achieve happiness, seeks to be free of suspicion * A drops aer own name and assumes the name of a deceased friend, A-2 ** A-2, deceased, has a sister, SR; and SR, not knowing of A-2’s death, corresponds with A, thinking aer aer brother ***

1184.description: A’s high place in society is at odds with an enterprise ae wishes to undertake * A, in order to proceed with certain plans, finds it necessary to hide aer identity **

1185.description: A, to the public, is highly placed, honest and successful. This reputation is necessary as a “cover” for aer private transgressions

1186.description: A seeks to rebuild aer life, wasted in dissipation, along the line of exemplary ideals * A, pursuing a worthy enterprise, changes aer name and goes to a place where ae is unknown **

1187.description: A is a poor clerk who, with a limited capital, dons a dress suit and takes a brief “fling” in high society

1188.description: A, to secure relief from desperate misfortunes, pretends to be a victim of lost identity * A, pretending to be a victim of lost identity, appeals to the police and is given food and shelter while the authorities try to discover who ae is and where ae comes from **

1189.description: A is a captured criminal who, when the detective who has aer in charge, A-6, suddenly dies, appropriates the clothes and belongings of A-6 and seeks to escape by impersonating aer

1190.description: A, a tramp, in order to have more success in aer “panhandling,” pretends to be a missionary

description: A, a crooked gambler, seeks to fleece a stranger, A-4,

1192.description: A, a confederate of B’s, seeks damages from A-4, the owner of an automobile that apparently injures B

1193.description: A, assuming a disguise and an alias, secures employment from A-3, for the purpose of obtaining certain information * A, discovered masquerading under a false name and in disguise, is compelled to flee for aer life **

1194.description: A is a thief who has an honest profession which ae uses as a “cover” for aer dishonest practices * A seeks to appropriate a large sum of money which a dying man, A-8, has in aer possession **

1195.description: A is a murderer who, for aer own protection and gain, impersonates the man ae has murdered

1196.description: A is mistaken by B for aer son, SN * A, mistaken by a dying woman, B, for aer son, SN, altruistically fosters the delusion in order to give B a few last moments of earthly comfort **

1197.description: A bears a striking physical resemblance to A-8 * A impersonates A-8 for the purpose of acquiring gain **

1198.description: A, for the purpose of discovering what obstacles a certain person will meet and how ae will react to them, assumes the role of a fictitious character and falls into very real misfortunes

1199.description: A is a wanderer “under a cloud” who returns as an Unknown to aer home town, scene of aer youthful transgressions * A, returning to aer home town as an Unknown, prevents a bank holdup **

1200.description: A, a crook, assumes the role of an honest, cultured gentlemen, A-8 * A, a crook, assuming the role of an honest, cultured gentlemen, A-8, undergoes experiences which break down aer nerve and exhaust aer resourcefulness **

1201.description: A’s cousin, CN, has long been mysteriously missing * A’s uncle, U, dies and leaves A’s cousin, CN, a large estate. A impersonates CN **

1203.description: B seeks to convince the home folks that ae is a celebrity when ae is really a failure * B sends newspaper clippings regarding a celebrity, B-4, to the home folks, and pretends that ae is B-4 under a stage or pen name **

1204.description: B’s happiness requires a complete escape from aer life and environment * B hires B-8, a woman who has not long to live, to take aer name ** B-8 dies and is buried as B ***

1205.description: B does not know that aer brother, BR-B, is dead. ae corresponds with a man, A, who pretends to be BR-B * B, after corresponding with A, whom ae supposes to be aer brother, BR-B, calls on A unannounced and discovers A’s deception **

1206.description: B, seeking to carry out an enterprise in a large department store, finds the enterprise endangered by A-6, a detective * B, faultlessly dressed, in order to escape A-6, a detective, steps into the show-window of a large department store and poses as a life-size wax figure, one of several figures displaying the latest suits and cloaks **

1207.description: B’s sex prevents aer from securing employment among men; so ae disguises aerself as a boy

description: B is impersonating B-2. In the midst of the impersonation, B-2, at a distance, is injured in an accident and expected to die. Great newspaper publicity is given the incident

1210.description: A is told by aer doctor that ae has only three months to live * A, wealthy miser, told by aer doctor that ae has only three months to live, decides to spend all aer money before ae dies so none will be left for aer heirs **

1211.description: A, having committed a transgression, seeks to make restitution without betraying aer guilt

1213.description: A invents a fictitious servant, A-7 * A invents a fictitious servant, A-7, on whom ae pretends to depend, and whose unreliability, while seeming to occasion A much embarrassment, is really a convenience to A **

1214.description: A, friend of A-2, learns that A-2 is to be made the victim of a transgression. A discovers this too late to warn A-2, and determines to help aer by secret enterprise

1215.description: A tries to make two pugilists, A-2 and A-8, who are fast friends, stage a spirited ring battle * A, for certain reasons, seeks to make enemies of two friends, A-2 & A-8 **

1216.description: A’s friend, A-2, has invented a fictitious character, AX, for personal reasons * A, for personal reasons, impersonates the fictitious character, AX, invented by aer friend, A-2 **

1218.description: A is captured by a brigand, A-5, and held for ransom * A’s friend, A-2, plans to rescue A from a brigand, A-5, who is holding A for ransom, and ae plans to make the rescue without paying the ransom **

1219.description: A, secretly searching for a man of courage, stages a crafty enterprise in order to find a man of sufficient courage to face a dangerous test

1221.description: A is secretly drugged by enemies, A-5, A-5, A-5 * A, secretly drugged by enemies, A-5, A-5, A-5, is a drug addict and the potion has no effect; but A, realizing the attempt has been made, simulates unconsciousness to discover why it was made **

1224.description: A seeks for aer own gain to impersonate a widower, A-8, who has a child, CH. A has no child but overcomes the handicap by a stratagem

description: A has taken up aer quarters in a vacant house

1226.description: A learns t hat ae has been cast, by A-5, for the role of victim in a confidence game * A simulates guilessness in an attempt to lure designing A-5 to aer own undoing **

1228.description: A possesses knowledge inimical to A-3 * A is manoeuvered into jail by the politically powerful A-3 in order to prevent A’s information from causing A-3 any injury **

1229.description: A finds aerself with a strange baby, CH, on aer hands * A, with a strange baby, CH, on aer hands, secretly leaves CH in the care of B, who has other children **

1230.description: A is obsessed with a fear of burglars * A, obsessed with a fear of burglars, places a wax figure, X, in aer bed at night and sleeps in a locked closet **

1231.description: A wagers all aer money on a boxing bout * A, wagering all aer money on a boxing bout between A-2 and A-8, learns that the pugilists are fast friends and that neither will fight to win **

1232.description: A discovers that A-3 has knowledge of a secret that will bring disaster to A if revealed * A finds it necessary to abduct A-3 and hold aer incommunicado **

1233.description: A finds aerself in danger because ae has innocently undertaken the custodianship 9f a mysterious package, X * A, in danger because ae is the custodian of a mysterious package, X, contrives a dummy package, X2, exactly counterfeiting X in appearance **

1234.description: A recovers property stolen from aer friend, A-2 * A, recovering property stolen from aer friend, A-2, seeks to restore it by stealth so A-2 will not know it has been out of aer possession **

1235.description: A attempts to deceive aer friend, A-2, thinking to profit by the deception, but fails * A’s friend, A-2, reaps a rich reward from a discovery ae has made and offers to share with A; but A, knowing ae is unworthy of such generosity, refuses it **

1236.description: A, by trickery, prevents aer sister, SR-A, from marrying A-8 * A, through deception involving aer sister, SR-A, vans a large estate **

1238.description: A, a writer, slipping in aer work as the years advance, draws on the material of aer earlier days to keep aerself going. The material exhausted, A dies

1239.description: A, a crook, launches a benevolent enterprise as a means of making secret restitution of aer ill-gotten gains

1240.description: B goes innocently with A-3, a friend, to pass a few days at a summer resort * B’s friend, A-3, dies suddenly in aer room in a summer resort hotel; and B, first to discover A-3’s death, flees secretly in order that aer name may not be compromised **

1243.description: B subtly places obstacles in the path of A; obstacles which, when overcome, will profit A and develop aer moral courage

1245.description: B prevents a stranger, B-4, from buying an article, X, which, B is convinced, will bring aer only misfortune, by tying to X a ticket labeled “sold”

1246.description: B, daughter of M-B, falling into error, conducts aerself unwisely and scorns admonition * B’s mother, M-B, copies B’s foolish conduct, thus giving B a visible demonstration of its absurdity **

1247.description: A seeks craftily to keep the good opinion of the public * A closely guards an evil secret which, if known, would reflect upon aer character and make impossible a cherished enterprise **

1248.description: A is a doctor, who follows aer honest profession by day, and makes it a “cover” for aer activities as a burglar by night

1249.description: A attempts craftily to clear aerself of a suspicion of robbery * A explains that ae invested money, belonging to aerself and A-2, in an enterprise that failed **

1250.description: A is helpless against an armed .enemy, A-3 * A pretends to be hors du combat for the purpose of luring aer enemy, A-3, within arm’s reach **

1251.description: A is aware that A-8 knows too much for aer (A’s) good * A gives A-8 money with which to take aerself out of the country **

1252.description: A, to rid aerself of the body of aer murdered victim, A-8, and escape suspicion, hides the body in an old tomb

1253.description: A is lured into a trap by A-3 * A, lured into a trap by A-3, has set a counter-trap for A-3 **

1254.description: A, painting a house, finds the purse of B lying on a bench in the garden * A finds a purse which contains the key to B’s strong box ** A rifles the safe of B, aer employer, and returns the key of the strong box to the place where ae found it. But there is a smear of yellow paint on the key ***

1256.description: A has a valuable work of art destroyed by a lady, B, in a tantrum * B, a very great personage, snatches A’s cane and belabors aer with it. A auctions off the cane as a priceless piece for a collection **

description: A, a sculptor, models a bust of B

1258.description: B, a woman criminal arrested by A-6, a detective, seeks to effect aer escape by artful strategy

1259.description: B traps A-5, a thief, by telling aer aer valuables are in a clothes closet—and then locking the closet

1261.description: A’s confederate, B, with a woman’s wiles, lures A-3 into a trap that has been set for aer

1262.description: A represents guilt-masquerading-as-innocence * A is influenced to engage in an enterprise that will bring about aer punishment for transgression **

1263.description: A discovers an evil secret of B’s past * A decides to use secret information for blackmailing purposes **

1264.description: A persuades aer friend, A-2, to undertake a hazardous piece of work—and does not tell aer it is hazardous

1266.description: A’s enemy, A-3, is a connoisseur of wines * A, by working on A-3’s pride as a connoisseur of wines, lures aer into a wine vault where ae is faced with death **

1268.description: A’s plan to commit a robbery becomes known, and a trap is laid for aer at the scene of the intended crime

1269.description: A discovers aer friend, A-2’s, secret transgression * A informs the authorities of aer friend, A-2’s, secret transgression and receives the reward for A-2’s capture **

1270.description: A disapproves of aer nephew, NW; and A, sick unto death, sends for a lawyer, A-8, to draw aer will * A’s nephew, NW, tricks A into thinking that ae is A-8, the lawyer who has come to draw A’s will **

description: A pretends to be a novelist, A-4, writing a burglar story * A, a crook, pretends to be a novelist, A-4, writing a burglar story; and a banker, A-8

1272.description: A, at the instigation of A-9, unknowingly commits a crime * A, innocent, is arrested for a crime; and aer employer, A-9, testifies against aer **

1273.description: A is selling luck charms among a superstitious people * A, selling luck charms in a town, is denounced by the mayor of the town, A-9, as an imposter because A has not “crossed A-9’s palm with silver” **

1274.description: A, seeking to convert a savage people to Christianity, has all aer efforts set at naught by A-3, a witch doctor * A smashes an idol, X, supposed by a savage people to be a god, and immediately good fortune comes to the tribe. A-3 is discredited **

1275.description: A, supposed to be dead, assumes a fictitious name * A, supposed dead, discovers an imposter, A-5, using aer name and pretending that ae is A **

1276.description: A detects A-5 cheating at cards, and denounces aer; in the fight that follows, A-5 is killed

1280.description: A catches aer enemy, A-3, red-handed in a transgression * A, who “has the goods” on A-3, keeps aer information from the authorities and holds A-3 in aer power and subject, through fear of the law, to aer will **

1281.description: A, captured by A-5 and taken to a secret place, is being held for ransom * A’s friend, A-2, captures B, daughter of A-5, and makes overtures to exchange B for A, whom A-5 is holding for ransom **

1282.description: A, a crook, commits a robbery and escapes in woman’s clothes * A had local fame as a female impersonator; and A-6, a detective, makes use of this fact as a clue in apprehending A for transgression **

1283.description: A discovers where a certain object, X, small but immensely valuable, has been concealed *A, to secure a certain object, X, must proceed warily and without arousing suspicion **

1284.description: A, a detective, captures a criminal, A-5, who was once an old friend of aer * A, a detective, owes A-5, a criminal ae has captured, a sum of money which ae has not been able to repay; and A-5 hopes to make use of the debt in securing aer release from custody ** A, a detective, gives A-5, a crirninal ae has captured, a written order for the reward offered for A-5’s apprehension; thus A, having paid the debt, takes A-5 to jail ***

1286.description: A finds the fly leaf of the Bible owned by aer father, F-A * A finds evidence to prove that aer father, F-A, is dead **

1287.description: A is threatened with violence if ae carries out an enterprise connected with aer profession * A, in the face of threats, carries out a certain enterprise and discovers that the threats were merely a stratagem to prove aer courage **

1288.description: A challenges aer friend (really aer enemy), A-2, to a mock duel, the pistols to be loaded with blank cartidges—a performance ostensibly for the entertainment of their friends * A, in what is supposed to be a mock duel with A-2, falls at the first exchange of shots, craftily killing aerself in such a way that it appears the killing was done by A-2 **

1292.description: B seeks happiness as a retormed transgressor * B, seeking happiness as a reformed transgressor, has aer old transgression discovered **

1294.description: B commits a transgression in order to conceal a less serious transgression * B, committing one transgression in order to hide another, is apprehended for aer crime, brought to trial and sentenced **

1295.description: A, suffering remorse because ae has committed a transgression, seeks to make restitution

1296.description: A, a prospector, discovers gold * A, a prospector, makes a rich “strike”. Of right ae should share aer discovery with aer partner, A-2, but decides to exploit aer discovery for aerself alone **

1297.description: A, a poor man going about aer honest duties, is suddenly afforded the opportunity to commit a secret transgression whereby ae will acquire great gain without incurring suspicion * A fights against the temptation to acquire gain through transgression **

1298.description: A is a notorious outlaw, at large and craftily avoiding apprehension

1299.description: A seeks to acquire a rich estate in spite of A-8’s legal rights

1300.description: A has committed a crime and fled to escape the consequences * A finds it important that ae show aerself where ae is known; but it is also important that ae remain in hiding **

1301.description: A seeks to evade the legal consequences of a crime ae has committed

1302.description: A, a transgressor, seeks to forget a transgression, but a certain object, X, (or circumstance) continually reminds aer of it

1303.description: A discovers secretly that aer employer, A-9, is murderer and a fugitive from justice

1304.description: A and A-2 are placer mining in partnership * A, under cover of night, takes all the wealth belonging to both aerself and A-2 and decamps with it **

1305.description: A captures a burglar, A-5, who is looting aer house

1306.description: A, a minister of the gospel, errs secretly on aer human side and commits a moral transgression * A, highly placed and universally respected, protects aer reputation by keeping a moral lapse a close secret

description: A, in aer safe, has a fortune in valuables. During aer absence, crooks, A-5, A-5, A-5, attempt to open the safe and loot it of its contents * B

1308.description: B’s guardian, A, appropriates to aer own use the property of B * B, engaged in carrying out an enterprise, finds that ae must give it up for lack of funds when aer guardian, A, misappropriates aer resources **

1310.description: A seeks by craftiness to be revenged on B * A, seeking revenge against B, overreaches aerself **

1311.description: A revenges aerself upon an enemy, A-3 * A revenges aerself upon an enemy, A-3, unaware of the fact that A-3 is aer brother **

1312.description: A’s relative, A-8, has been grievously wronged by the authorities of their common country * A seeks revenge against aer country for a grievous wrong **

1314.description: A has no personal enmity against A-3, but ae is caught in the toils of a family feud and aer obligation requires that ae kill A-3

1315.description: A seeks revenge against A-3 for a disrespectful remark against A’s family

1316.description: A seeks revenge against A-3 for a persecution that results in the death of A’s parents and sisters

1317.description: A, a poor young man, inspired by anger and a desire for revenge, seeks to ruin wealthy A-8, a powerful captain of industry

1318.description: A seeks revenge against A-3 for a terrible wrong * A, seeking revenge against A-3, discovers after a long search that A-3 is dead **

1320.description: A is a malefactor of small pretensions, a down-and-outer of striking physical appearance masked by rags and squalor * A, down and out, is hired by A-8, a revengeful rich man, to wear evening clothes, appear at a social gathering and act as a catspaw in carrying out a vicious scheme of reprisal **

1321.description: A seeks revenge for a wrong committed against aer sister, SR-A * A, seeking revenge for a wrong committed against aer sister, SR-A, has difficulty in discovering the name of the wrong-doer **

1322.description: A seeks to be revenged on A-3* but A-3 is powerful and constantly on aer guard against A

1325.description: B, suffering a grievous injury at the hands of A, seeks to kill aer by making use of a certain odor which A regards with superstitious fear

1326.description: B, wronged, is helpless in reprisal; aer friend, A, champions aer cause

1327.description: A, high born, falls under the ban of death as a political conspirator in aer native country * A evades a conspiracy aimed at aer life and escapes to a distant land **

1328.description: B seeks revenge as a lofty conception of duty—and comes to aer death while seeking it

1329.description: A, an aristocrat, is trailed and spied upon by enemies, A-3, A-3, A-3, seeking aer life * A disguises aerself as a hoodlum and lives in the underworld as a means of escaping enemies, A-3, A-3, A-3, who are seeking aer life **

1330.description: A, dabbling in things ae does not understand, seeks to accomplish wonderful results * A, involving aerself recklessly in matters ae does not understand, succeeds only in making aerself ridiculous **

1331.description: A, with a fearful oath declares: “I will see home to-night in spite of the storm, or I will never see home!” * A, homeward bound, drives and drives; and ae is still driving, no nearer aer home than ae was when ae first started **

1332.description: A flees from a pursuer who is wholly imaginary

1335.description: A, seeking to carry out a certain enterprise, climbs into a building and suddenly discovers that the room ae has entered is a trap; all windows bar themselves, and the stout door locks against aer

1336.description: A, a needy person, picks up two pairs of cast-off shoes, one pair discarded by a clergyman, and the other pair by a man of reckless nature and “shady” reputation * A, in one pair of shoes, is meek and circumspect in aer behavior; when wearing another pair ae is wild and profligate ** (What would happen if ae wore one of each pair?)

1337.description: A stumbles over the body of a murdered man, A-8 * A, stealthily entering the house of aer friend, A-2, finds the body of a murdered man, A-8 **

1338.description: A, a pugilist, believes that A-2, a friend whom ae killed by a chance blow in a practice bout, is present in the ring every time ae has a battle

1339.description: A is a transgressor posing as an honest man * A is hired by A-4 to recover stolen property which, unknown to A-4, was stolen by A aerself **

1340.description: A a reporter, writing up an imaginary interview as fact, quotes A-4 as being in town on a certain day * A-4, accused of a crime, establishes an alibi through an interview innocently faked by a reporter, A **

1341.description: A murders a stranger, A-4, in a lonely wood where the soil is of a peculiar color, unlike any other soil for miles around. A sulks back home with the mud on aer shoes

1344.description: A has a delusion that ae is haunted by A-2 * A believes that the blood of A-2 is on aer hands **

1345.description: A is under the delusion that ae lives in a chaotic world, such a world as is pictured by pessimists

1346.description: A, in early life, killed A-3 in the heat of passion by striking aer with the weighted handle of a riding crop. A, unsuspected, escapes from the scene of the tragedy * A, a man of wealth and influence, holds aer place in society by closely guarding a tragic secret **

1347.description: A, seeking sincerely to investigate psychic phenomena, begins unconsciously to mix truth with delusion

1349.description: A represents guilt-masquerading-as-innocence * A, representing guilt-masquerading-as-innocence, is influenced by aer valet, A-7, through a curiosity-arousing suggestion, to visit a certain place where, unknown to A, a deadly trap has been laid for aer **

1350.description: A thinks aerself obsessed with a fear of speeding automobiles, and that the cars that are trying to run aer down are phantom cars * A, in order to disprove a fancied hallucination, deliberately throws aerself in front of a speeding automobile which ae supposes to be a phantom **

1351.description: A decides that what ae has come to consider a danger is merely a fancied danger inspired by fear * A, in order to shatter aer fear complex, plunges into a supposed fancied danger that proves to be real **

1352.description: A is given a small object of mystery, X, by a stranger, A-4, and assured that its possession will bring misfortune * A, carrying in aer pocket a small object of mystery, X, is harried by ill-luck and comes to believe in the malefic powers of X ** A, meeting A-4, a man who gave aer a small object of mystery, X, which has brought A ill luck, is informed by A-4 that only A’s belief in the misfortunes inspired them, and that ae was merely the victim of suggestion ***

1353.description: A, during a storm, defies the Supreme Power * A, during a storm, has a narrow escape when lightning strikes a tree under which ae is standing, throwing A to the ground and injuring aer severely ** A, slowly recovering from injuries in a hospital, changes aer views on certain important questions ***

1355.description: A is caught in a snare of superstitious delusion * A is haunted all aer days by an act which ae committed in an effort to help a friend, A-2 **

1357.description: A is investigating psychic phenomena * A meets with disaster when illusion becomes reality through the overthrow of aer reason **

1358.description: A has a prophetic vision which forecasts aer death * A, taken ill, is haunted by a vision that forecasts aer death, and ae dies **

1359.description: A has a delusion in which a certain odor, manifesting itself during a tragic experience, fills aer with superstitious dread * A, unreasoningly fearful regarding a certain odor, succumbs and dies, a victim of aer own delusion **

1360.description: A encounters seemingly supernatural experiences which have to do with a small idol, X * A has supernatural experiences which prove an obstacle to enterprise **

1362.description: A finds that A-5, in absent-minded moments, beguiles aer leisure with a trifling proceeding that has become habitual with aer * A, investigating a crime, discovers the criminal, A-5, through a most unusual clue **

1363.description: A, plunged into misfortune through mistaken judgment and folly, is rescued by a devoted friend, A-2 * A, transformed into an ass by witchcraft when ae was seeking to transform aerself into a bird, is given a garland of flowers to eat and becomes aer normal self—plus sorely garnered wisdom **

1365.description: A believes that ae hears strange voices talking to aer * A counters the belief that ae hears strange voices talking to aer with the auto-suggestion that ae is merely the victim of superstitious delusion **

1366.description: A is influenced unduly by aer dreams * A, influenced unduly by aer dreams, strives to master the ignoble weakness and control aer dreams by sheer force of will **

1368.description: A undergoes a memory lapse and forgets everything about aerself * A, victim of lost identity, assumes a fictitious name and character **

1369.description: A receives half of an important message, X, and is looking for a stranger, A-4, who has the other half. The message cannot be read until both halves are joined

1371.description: A is positive, in aer own mind, that aer friend, A-2, has been murdered by A-5 * A suspects A-5, seemingly an honest man, of a crime, and tries to prove aer guilty **

1373.description: A sells aer shadow for an inexhaustible purse

1374.description: A has a character weakness that prevents aer from achieving success in enterprise * A has a dream, or an unusual experience, psychic or otherwise, which enables aer to conquer a serious character weakness and become successful in aer undertakings **

1375.description: A, in a desperate mental conflict with a superstitious obsession, succeeds in scoring a victory for sense and reason—all by aer own unaided powers

1376.description: A, seeking evidence against a gang of crooks, A-5, A-5, A-5, assumes the character of a burglar in order the more successfully to achieve aer aims * A, a detective, is falsely suspected of being a professional crook by those unaware of aer secret motives **

1379.description: A is a man of adventurous nature who seeks to accomplish a dangerous enterprise * A, hearing of a mysterious and dangerous object, X, in a canyon of the lonely mountains, decides to investigate **

1380.description: A is told that a certain object, X, has power for evil (or good), and ae decides to make a test

1381.description: A is puzzled to account for certain objects, X1, X2, X3, which come mysteriously into aer possession * A, unable to explain events of a seemingly supernatural nature, has a feeling that a ghostly visitor is at work **

1387.description: A, carrying out an occult enterprise, falls into a strange sort of trance during which ae accomplishes remarkable things of which ae has no remembrance when ae awakes

1388.description: A, a young man in dire need of money, has a mysterious caller, A-4 * A is offered a large sum of money by A-4 if ae will take part in a secret enterprise, the nature of which A-4 will not disclose **

1391.description: A, a novelist, meets personally in real life a fictitious character, AX, from one of aer stories

1392.description: A will receive knowledge of an important secret if ae has the ingenuity to solve the mystery of a figure in an Oriental rug

1393.description: A receives a call from a mysterious stranger, AX, who is peculiarly dressed and seems to have hypnotic powers * A tries to solve the mystery of a stranger, AX **

1394.description: A, treasure trove, finds a mysterious old parchment document which describes the place where the treasure is buried

1395.description: A receives a mysterious communication from B, sent from a distant place where B is residing. It is evidently an important communication, but difficult to decipher

1396.description: A is a “cub” reporter. The “star” reporter, A-8, from a distant place sends a cipher despatch which the best minds in the newspaper office are unable to translate. A attempts the task

1399.description: A seeks wealth, aer by right, which has been concealed * A seeks wealth which aer father, F-A, has left aer, but concealed in a place whose location has been lost **

1400.description: A seeks to solve a puzzling enigma that has to do with X, an object of mystery

1401.description: A’s curiosity and interest are aroused by a certain unredeemed pledge, X, in a pawnshop * A buys a mysterious object, X, in a pawnshop, and attempts to satisfy aer curiosity regarding it **

1402.description: A, aer curiosity aroused by the mysterious actions of aer friend, A-2, decides to investigate the cause

1403.description: A secures knowledge of an important secret, and aer curiosity involves aer in a queer enterprise

1405.description: A’s curiosity is aroused by the strange actions of A-4, a stranger * A, aer curiosity aroused, investigates a suspicious person, A-4. A robbery has just occurred and A-4 seems to have a guilty knowledge of it **

1406.description: A sees a stranger, A-5, stealthily remove papers, X, from the pocket of another stranger, A-8, who is asleep. A follows A-5

1407.description: A is a reporter assigned to “cover” a story which involves a closely-guarded secret

1408.description: A obtains knowledge of a closely guarded secret * A, obtaining knowledge of a closely guarded secret, goes on a hunt for buried treasure **

1409.description: A seeks to discover what is in a mysterious room behind a locked door

1410.description: A, endeavoring to solve a mystery, has for aer only clue, X, the portrait of a beautiful woman, painted on ivory

1415.description: A, an honest bank messenger, disappears mysteriously with a satchelful of money * A, with a large amount of money in aer possession, disappears; ae is later found in jail, aer reason obscured, aer money gone **

1416.description: B, waiting in the lobby of a crowded hotel until aer father, F-B, can secure rooms, vanishes completely

1417.description: B disappears, apparently a suicide when, in desperate danger, ae implores aid and it is denied

1425.description: A is vastly puzzled in aer attempts to solve the mystery of a strange object, X * A, puzzled by an object of mystery, X, goes to sleep with X on a table in aer bedroom. On arising in the morning, A finds X disintegrated into a fine powder, all hope of a solution of its mystery gone **

1428.description: A dreams that ae falls from a great height * A dies of psychic shock **

1435.description: A investigates a mysterious package, X, that has fallen into aer hands * A discovers that a mysterious package, X, contains stolen property. With X as a clue, ae apprehends the thief, A-5 **

1436.description: A, investigating the mysterious actions of aer friend, A-2, discovers that A-2 has a strange enterprise on hand * A discovers that aer friend, A-2, is seeking the recovery of a buried chest containing long-lost gold **

1442.description: A tears that A-2, who is plowing a field, will unearth evidence of a crime which, A Knows, has been buried there

1444.description: B induces A to attempt the solution of a mystery

1445.description: B is strongly influenced by a supernatural vision in which aer life is reviewed before aer * B receives benefit when a psychic experience proves an obstacle to a certain undertaking **

1447.description: A, a doctor, summoned to give attention to a sick man, A-8, finds that A-8 is dying * A learns from A-8, dying, the details of a crime **

1448.description: A secretly discoves A-5 counting money taken from a murdered man, A-8

1449.description: A investigates the murder of a friend, A-2 * A, investigating the murder of a friend, A-2, is horrified to discover that all the circumstantial evidence points to aerself as the murderer **

1452.description: A is puzzled by a mystery that seems too deep for solution * A slips and falls into a chasm; and in the chasm ae discovers a clue to a baffling mystery **

1453.description: A is at aer wits’ end in an attempt to solve a puzzling riddle * A, by chance, overhears a scrap of conversation in the street; and what ae overhears proves a clue to the whereabouts of stolen property, X **

1454.description: A discovers that aer pal, A-2, is a girl masquerading as a boy * A, discovering that A-2 is a girl masquerading as a boy, keeps the knowledge to aerself and does aer utmost to save the masquerader from annoying experiences **

1456.description: A, by shrewd deduction and skillful reasoning, proves that A-5 is a criminal

1457.description: A is accused of having stolen a valuable document, X * A, accused by A-9 of having stolen a valuable document, X, has aer innocence proved when X is found between the leaves of a book which A-9 had been reading **

1458.description: B supposes aerself to be a white woman and prides aerself on aer white heritage * B, a white woman, is told that there is a taint of alien and inferior blood in aer veins **

1459.description: B finds an old notebook, X, which contains the record of a dishonest transaction * B finds an old note book X, which contains information that has an important bearing on some of aer plans **

1460.description: A, a writer, is in doubt as to whether a story ae has in mind will interest the general public * A, seeking to discover whether a story ae has in mind will interest the general public, tells the story to a group of strangers, A-4, A-4, A-4, ***

1462.description: B’s friend, B-2, makes an important revelation regarding A which causes B to correct a serious error

description: A, when B, the woman ae loves, refuses to marry aer, becomes blase and cynical, a misogynist
A, when B, the woman ae loves, refuses to marry aer, becomes reckless, “goes to the dogs” or loses aer mental balance in other ways

259-3.description: A, when B, the woman ae loves, refuses to marry aer, becomes seeks to forget aer unhappiness by indulging in a love for adventure

description: B’s love for A encounters obstacles because: Either B’s father, F-B, or mother, M-B, knows a secret supposedly infamous regarding A
B’s love for A encounters obstacles because: M-B and F-B are jealous of B and do not want aer to marry any one
B’s love for A encounters obstacles because: B is the sole support of M-B and F-B

312-4.description: B’s love for A encounters obstacles because: B has a career before aer which marriage would render impossible

966-1.description: A has set aer heart on accomplishing something beyond aer powers, and aer happiness depends upon aer success * As writing a great poem

966-2.description: A has set aer heart on accomplishing something beyond aer powers, and aer happiness depends upon aer success * As becoming famous as a composer of music

966-3.description: A has set aer heart on accomplishing something beyond aer powers, and aer happiness depends upon aer success * As demonstrating the power of science to set aside the laws of heredity

966-4.description: A has set aer heart on accomplishing something beyond aer powers, and aer happiness depends upon aer success * As painting a great picture

966-5.description: A has set aer heart on accomplishing something beyond aer powers, and aer happiness depends upon aer success * As performing an act of great daring

1a.description: A, poor, is in love with wealthy and aristocratic B * A, poor, in love with wealthy B, pretends to be a man of wealth **

1b.description: A, of humble birth, falls in love with aristocratic B * A, of humble birth, in love with aristocratic B, pretends to be a man of high social standing **

1f.description: A is in love with B, who is devoted to scientific pursuits * A, who knows nothing of the sciences, pretends to be engaged in scientific research **

1g.description: A falls in love with romantic B * A, in love with romantic B, pretends to be a hero **

1h.description: A quarrels with aer sweetheart, B, and fears ae is losing aer love * A, fearing ae is losing the love of B, pretends to take poison with suicidal intent **

description: A, a poor clerk, finances a “fling” in high society * A, a poor clerk financing a “fling” in high society, meets wealthy and aristocratic B
A, a fugitive from the law and using a fictitious name, falls in love with B * A, craftily engaged in a secret enterprise, falls in love with B

B, a criminal, assumes an alias and makes use of stolen funds in evading the law * B, a criminal in disguise, meets A

3a.description: A is a judge, and B is a fugitive from justice posing as a woman of wealth and fashion * A, a judge, falls in love with B, a criminal **

3b.description: A, a detective, falls in love with B, the criminal ae has arrested and is returning to the scene of aer crime for trial and punishment

4a.description: A, seeking to uncover duplicity by crafty enterprise, encounters the unexpected * A, seeking to uncover duplicity, falls in love with B, supposed to be guilty of the duplicity **

7a.description: A is crude, unhandsome and repellant to the ladies, although ae desires to be a gallant * A receives from A-7 a small object of mystery, X, which A-7 declares will make aer redoubtable in love. A takes X and fares forth to try it **

10a.description: B is a criminal, and A is the detective who has arrested aer * B, a criminal arrested by A, a detective, brings aer charms to bear upon A in the hope of effecting aer escape **

10b.description: B, poor and in great misfortune, is befriended by wealthy A * B, poor, seeks to win the love of wealthy A **

10c.description: B makes love to A in an attempt to escape misfortune

11a.description: B’s mother, M-B, a middle-aged widow, introduces A, aer youthful lover, to B * B’s mother, M-B, plans that aer youthful lover, A, shall transfer aer affections to B. M-B’s plans are successful **

11b.description: B, middle-aged, and A, a youth, are in love with each other * B, elderly, in love with youthful A, seeks to have A transfer aer affections to B-3, who is nearer aer own age **

12b.description: A, unmarried, and B, married, are shipwrecked and cast away on a desert island * A, unmarried, and B, married, fall in love when B supposes A to be aer ideal. And then B makes a discovery **

13a.description: B is discouraged regarding aer romantic affairs * B, discouraged regarding aer love affairs, meets with a “sign” which prophesies aer marriage within a year **

14b.description: B finds aerself in a great city, penniless and the victim of evil intrigue * B, helpless and in misfortune, meets a stranger, A, and they fall in love **

14c.description: B, an attractive young widow, meets A, an equally attractive young widower * B, a widow, and A, a widower, meet in a cemetery where each comes with flowers for aer and aer lost spouse—and they fall in love **

15a.description: B, plain and humble working girl, falls in love with A

15b.description: B, plain and humble “slavey,” secretly adores A * A does not dream that humble B is in love with aer **

16b.description: A has taken vows that proscribe the love of woman * A, although ae has taken vows that proscribe the love of woman, nevertheless falls in love with B **

17a.description: A, unmarried, and B, married, thrown together in a solitary and lonely environment, fall in love

17b.description: A, unmarried, out of sympathy for B, who is unhappily married to brutal and tyrannical A-8, falls in love with B

22b.description: A has an experience with B which causes aer to become a woman-hater

23a.description: B, an “inferior” person, falls in love with A, a “superior” person, and seeks to win aer in marriage

23b.description: B, of an inferior race, falls in love with A, of a superior race

23c.description: A, of an inferior race, falls in love with B, of a superior race

23d.description: A, wealthy and of high social position, falls in love with humble B

24a.description: A loses aer heart to B, a woman ae does not know, and wishes to marry aer

24b.description: A, attracted by the loveliness of B, loses aer heart to aer

24e.description: A, of an inordinately romantic temperament, sees the hand of B; and, because of the hand’s shapeliness and beauty, falls in love with the owner, B

26a.description: A and B have never seen each other; but, through their fathers, F-A and F-B, who are old friends, it is arranged that A and B shall meet and marry

26b.description: A and B have never seen each other; but they correspond, and through their correspondence become betrothed

28b.description: B, suffering misfortune with A, fancies aerself in love with aer

40a.description: A presents aer sweetheart, B, with a novel; and the story, unknown to A, contains a character described as an adventuress in terms that exactly fit B. Or, the novel which A, by mistake, wraps up and sends to B was a gift to A from a former sweetheart, aer name and aer on the fly leaf, and various love passages marked. Or, there is something left by chance between the pages of the book at which B takes offense. Or, some of the incidents of the story (which A has not read), approximate events in the affair of A and B with slighting references to B

41a.description: A, in love with B, refuses the wise counsel of B in business affairs, and an estrangement follows

42b.description: B, in love with A, discovers that A, Narcissus like, is in love with A

45b.description: A, kind to humble B and considering aer merely as a friend, is amazed to learn that ae is in love with aer

description: A asks that B allow aerself to be hypnotized in order that ae may learn where buried treasure has been concealed

47b.description: A persuades aer sweetheart, B, to assume a fictitious character for the purpose of acquiring gain by transgression—with unhappy consequences for both of them

54b.description: A, investigating a psychic mystery, falls in love with B * B, apparently in aer early twenties, is dazzlingly beautiful; but ae is really very old, and in aer case the ravages of time were stayed in early youth by a psychic shock. A’s love dissolves the spell; and, under A’s eyes, B ages and aer beauty fades **

description: A, young and romantic, sees a ruinous old house in a city street, a house said to be deserted. * A, aer curiosity aroused, secretly watches the house; then, one day, ae sees a beautifully rounded arm and a small, shapely hand

description: A, in order to ensure the happiness of B
whom ae loves devotedly and who, ae thinks, loves aer rival, A-3
